section.para: First step is defining which lifecycle management strategy is required for your tests. Depending on kind of test you are implementing (unit test, integration test, deployment test, ...) you will require an embedded approach, managed approach or remote approach.

section.title: Remote Lifecycle
section.para: Configuring remote approach does not require any special rule because you (or System like Maven ) is the responsible of starting and stopping the server. This mode is used in deployment tests where you are testing your application on real environment.

section.para: Next step is configuring HBase rule in charge of maintaining HBase columns into known state by inserting and deleting defined datasets. You must register HBaseRule JUnit rule class, which requires a configuration parameter with some information.

example.title: HBase with managed configuration

section.para: By default configuration used is the one loaded by calling HBaseConfiguration.create() method. HBaseConfiguration.create() which uses hbase-site.xml and hbase-default.xml classpath files.
But also a method setProperty method is provided to modify any parameter of generated configuration object.

section.title: Remote Connection
section.para:
Configuring a connection to remote HBase uses same approach like ManagedHBase configuration object but using com.lordofthejars.nosqlunit.hbase.RemoteHBaseConfigurationBuilder
class instead of com.lordofthejars.nosqlunit.hbase.ManagedHBaseConfigurationBuilder. .

warning.para: Working with Apache HBase required a bit of knowledge about how it works. For example your /etc/hosts file cannot contain a reference to your host name with ip 127.0.1.1.

Moreover NoSQLUnit uses HBase-0.94.1 and this version should be also installed in your computer to work with managed or remote approach. If you install another version, you should exclude these artifacts from NoSQLUnit dependencies, and add the new ones manually to your pom file.
